title: People keep falling in this canal because they think the algae is grass
text:
Steve Worthington said he and his 11-year-old son, Lewis, stepped straight into the waterway (Picture: BPM Media)

A canal is so covered with weeds that three people have fallen in believing it to be a path covered in grass.

Three people fell in during the course of one evening on October 5, when they thought the waterway was a path.

One of the victims was a teenager, who had just been to Nando’s in Walsall, West Midlands.

The 19-year-old stepped straight into the water and was barely able to keep his head up as he was unable to swim.

He was thankfully pulled out by friends, with the help of a passer by, and made his way to a nearby Premier Inn where hotel staff gave him towels so he could dry himself off before heading home.

His mother, who wished to remain anonymous, said the incident, which happened at around 7.30pm on October 4, had left her son ‘traumatised’.

The canal is choked with weeds (Picture: BPM Media)

She added: ‘My son was with his friends and saw what looked like a grass path, so walked on it and just fell in. He said he was in there for about 20 seconds.

‘He saw what looked like a tyre at the bottom so he put his foot on that to push him up a bit. Luckily his two friends and a passer by pulled him out, my son can’t swim.’

The mother-of-two, who lives in Darlaston, said when her son was ‘soaked’ when he arrived home.

She continued: ‘I thought he was joking when he first told me. It gave him such a shock, it has left us all feeling shocked about what happened.

‘This could happen to anyone, something needs to be done – or are they waiting for someone to fall in and die. I just thank God he came out with the help of friends and a passer by. It’s horrible thinking about what could have happened.’

It appears to be covered in grass (Picture: BPM Media)

The teen’s fall would have happened a matter of minutes before Steve Worthington and his 11-year-old son, Lewis, stepped straight into the water – also believing the weeds were grass .

The 41-year-old had to battle to keep his lad’s head above the water as they desperately tried to clamber to safety.

‘We just stepped straight in and went straight under the water,’ he said.

‘We have never been down there and we couldn’t see any warning signs in place. The whole area is thick green weeds – it looks just like grass.

A spokesman for the Canal & River Trust, which oversees the waterway near to the site, said: ‘We are aware that there is a problem with an overgrowth of weed in the basin, which can make it seem as though the area is covered in thick grass, hiding the water underneath.

‘Safety signs have been installed at the basin warning people of the danger. Removing the weed is an ongoing battle and there will be a team from Canal & River Trust out in the basin to clear sections of the weed in the next few days.’
